Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: An Exploratory Approach for Managing Multiple Flows in Serial Supply Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The success of a modern global supply chains is determined to a large extent by how flows of items (e.g., products, messages, and customers) are managed through multi-stage, inter-connected nodes/locations. Multi-stage systems are encountered throughout the realm of economic activity: in manufacturing systems where production proceeds through distinct stages; in logistics networks in which goods are transported from one location to another; and in communication networks in which messages are transmitted from one node to the next. Because of the complexity of such systems, many if not most firms still struggle to effectively control inventory, especially in the presence of multiple flows of product. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) supported research aims to advance methods to optimally manage inventory in such multi-stage systems, and thus reduce the cost of supply chain operations. This project will also provide educational opportunities for doctoral and master's students and help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and business education.

The main mathematical challenge for the study of complex supply chains lies in the multi-dimensional nature of the boundary of the feasible region for corresponding stochastic optimization problems. Unlike classical multi-echelon inventory problems with only the regular flow of product, multi-stage systems with multiple flows of product do not admit a reduction to a single-dimensional boundary of the feasible region. A main goal of this research is explore a new mathematical framework for solving multi-stage systems, based on establishing a weak decomposition of the objective cost function. By developing new results in convex analysis that pertain to the preservation of this weak decomposition under minimization, this research will then aim to provide effective and actionable policies to manage multi-stage systems with multiple flows of product. These control policies will make it possible to design fast and robust algorithms to optimally control such systems and evaluate the realized savings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project was concerned with finding new methods to analyze and better manage supply chains with multiple flows of product, as such supply chains are increasing encountered in practice. Traditional means of supply chain analysis assume that a product can only flow in a single direction; namely, downstream, from, for example, the supplier to the manufacturer to the distributor to the retailer. At the same time, different product flows have been gaining increasing prominence in industry. In particular, reverse logistics, which refers to principles and practices for managing the flow of surplus inventory back through the supply chain, reached $200 billion in value in 2013. Secondary markets have also increasingly come to represent the means of dealing with the surplus of stock, as secondary market sales of in-process supply chain inventory reached $300 billion in 2015.

In spite of those developments in industry, there remained a notable absence of analytical methods to manage those multiple flows of product in the supply chain in a way that maximizes resulting savings. Our research project addressed this gap between practice and theory by developing new solutions methods for solving large-scale, multi-stage, inventory problems with multiple flows of product. Our solution methods and the resulting algorithms developed in our project help companies to quickly and efficiently compute optimal decisions pertaining to how much inventory to move downstream in expectation of satisfying customer orders, how much overstock inventory to send by reverse flow upstream, and how much excess stock to sell off at each stage in the supply chain. In addition, our project also identified which form of demand uncertainty matters when it comes to making such decisions. We discovered that, even if demand in inherently uncertain within each period, but stationary from one period to another, it is never optimal to either sell off excess inventory in the secondary market or send it by reverse flow back through the supply chain. Consequently, the results of our project can also serve to inform companies of the need to distinguish between different sources of uncertainty in their supply chains, and to help them understand under what conditions it is not necessary to set up reverse logistics and secondary market sales capabilities. More generally, our results can enable firms to better manage their supply chains and raise their performance by providing them with the means to improve the operation of multi stage/node/location systems under their control.

Another practical outcome of our research project is the development of a simulator that enables managers or students to manage multi-stage supply chains with multiple flows of product. The users of the software can specify which flows they want to manage, how many stages in the supply chain they want to manage and for how many periods. They can also specify a variety of cost and revenue parameters in the models. Our project also made it possible for us to support a PhD student who was able to complete his Ph.D. studies, go on the job market and obtain a tenure-track faculty position at University of Utah.
